Hi Patrik,

 

It would be helpful to remove the handle and see what the nakago looks like.
However, from the outside, there are basically two choices from my point of
view: made in China, which seems very likely, or a poorly done Yokohama-mono
or cheap export sword from the Meiji period or later. Rich has supplied a
third option (modern export model) and has been far more politic than I. In
the future, I would refrain from paying money of such things. You would be
better off spending your money on some (more) books.

 

Gordon

 

  _____  

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Richard Turner
Sent: Thursday, November 27, 2008 6:42 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question about a small Tanto or??

 

Hi Patrik, my personal opinion is this may be modern. If it is a tourist 
piece, I think it could be Shouwa period at the earliest.

Best wishes

Richard

Patrik Danielsson wrote:
>
> Hello everybody, i bought this small "tanto" on an ad here in Sweden.
> Its feel really genunine, some kind of hard wood whith nice graining 
> in saya and tsuka, on some places it looks like all the brass has been 
> silverplated (can still se it above tha habaki on one of the photos), 
> i have not been able to take the tsuka of it yet,but i gonna do 
> that,(depending of the answers here :-)
> Can this be a "tourist" thing , or is it made for a child , women or 
> something like that?, if someone have some info age or something i 
> will really happy.
>
> The blade from grip (above habaki) to tip is 6.5 inches / 17 cm, and 
> the total is 10 inches/ 25.5 cm.
